clinical_study.brief_title: Network-Level Effects of Nitrous Oxide in the Human Brain
clinical_study.official_title: Network-Level Effects of Nitrous Oxide in the Human Brain

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to understand how a commonly used drug, nitrous oxide, acts on the brain to reduce pain. Nitrous oxide is commonly used in anesthesiology but there is limited knowledge on how this drug affects functional networks in the brain.

detailed_description.textblock: The objective of this study is to identify the network transformations that account for the analgesic effects of nitrous oxide. Our hypothesis is that analgesic doses of nitrous oxide increase network efficiency and disrupt normal pain processingOur approach is to administer subanesthetic nitrous oxide during the acquisition of fMRI (functional magnetic resonance imaging) and EEG (electroencephalogram).

primary_outcome.description: Brain imaging data will be obtained from functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data recorded simultaneously with electroencephalogram (EEG) data at baseline and under a sub-anesthetic dose of nitrous oxide. For fMRI we will use both seed-based techniques run primarily with Statistical Parametric Mapping (SPM) software to analyze brain connectivity prior to and during low dose nitrous. Seed-to-whole brain functional connectivity (i.e. correlated; e.g. Fishers-transformed z) will be measured using brain regions previously shown to be involved in pain and sensory processing as seed-regions of interests. A whole brain general linear model will be performed using the seed time course, averaged over a 3 mm radius sphere, as the regressor of interest, to find other brain regions also correlated with the seed region.

primary_outcome.measure: Functional connectivity associated with tonic stimulus
primary_outcome.description: Brain imaging data will be obtained from functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data recorded simultaneously with electroencephalogram (EEG) data at rest and during a tonic cuff stimulation. Seed-to-whole brain functional connectivity (i.e. correlated, e.g. Fishers-transformed z) will be measured using brain regions previously shown to be involved in pain and sensory processing as seed-regions of interests. Changes in connectivity (e.g. Fishers-transformed z) will be measured via contrast images that were created between conditions, stimulus minus rest at baseline and during nitrous oxide administration.

secondary_outcome.measure: Tonic stimulus intensity during nitrous oxide
secondary_outcome.description: Participants will receive a tonic (6 minutes) pressure applied to the lower leg at baseline and under sub-anesthetic dose of nitrous oxide. Following each pressure stimulus, participants will rate the pain intensity of the tonic stimulus (0 ="no pain", 10= "worst pain imaginable", Visual Analog Scale, e.g pain intensity).

secondary_outcome.measure: Spectral Power of Sub-anesthetic dose of Nitrous Oxide
secondary_outcome.description: Brain imaging data will be obtained from functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data recorded simultaneously with electroencephalogram (EEG) data at baseline and under a sub-anesthetic dose of nitrous oxide. Spectral data during the baseline and sub-anesthetic dose of nitrous to observe changes in spectral power.

arm_group.description: Each volunteer will participate in one scanning visit in which simultaneous fMRI/EEG data will be collected wherein they receive placebo (20 minutes) followed by inhaled nitrous oxide at subanalgesic levels (35% inhaled concentration) over 40 minutes.

intervention.description: Each volunteer will participate in one scanning visit in which simultaneous fMRI/EEG data will be collected wherein they receive placebo (20 minutes) followed by inhaled nitrous oxide at subanesthetic levels (35% inhaled concentration) over 40 minutes.
